metadata.titleEn: The slope map of the Tibetan Plateau (2000)
metadata.description:
This data set contains the digital slope distribution and slope degree data of the Tibetan Plateau, which can be used to assist in basic geographic information analysis and research work on the Tibetan Plateau region. The raw data were the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) data provided by Global Land Cover Network (GLCN) using the WGS84 coordinate system, and the raw data were framing data, including latitude and longitude data, with a spatial resolution of 3″. After the mosaic processing, the Nodata (null data) generated in the mosaic process were interpolated and filled, and after filling, a projection conversion process was performed to generate an equal-area conical projection of the data bit Albers, after conversion projection, the spatial resolution was 90 m. Finally, the boundary of the Tibetan Plateau was used for cutting to obtain DEM data. Use the spatial analysis module under ArcMap to calculate the slope aspect and generate the slope map. 
Field: value
Data type: floating point
Interpretation: slope degree
Dimension: degree
Data accuracy: spatial resolution 90 m

background: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission produced the most complete, highest-resolution digital elevation model of the Earth. The project was a joint endeavor of NASA, the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency, and the German and Italian Space Agencies and flew in February 2000. At the foundation of modern geosciences, quite literally, is knowledge of the shape of the Earth’s surface. Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality: some with astounding accuracy, some far less adequate. It has proven exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means. The emergence, in the 1990s, of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry placed the possibility of efficiently and affordably creating a global digital elevation model within the grasp of spacefaring nations. Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, makes use of phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio (typically 0.0002) to measure topography.
research objective: The SRTM objective was to acquire a digital elevation model of all land between about 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, about 80% of Earth’s land surface. The operational goal of C radar was to generate contiguous mapping coverage as called for by the mission objectives. X radar was included as an experimental demonstration. As it did not employ ScanSAR, the X band radar had a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) than the C band system. The key to successful acquisition of a data set suitable for automated production is to remove the variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and to measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects accurately at all times during data acquisition.
challenges: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality: some with astounding accuracy, some far less adequate. Furthermore, the global coverage has been uneven. It has proven exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means. Optical stereo mapping systems suffer from poor control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and from persistent cloud cover in many important areas of the world.
methods: Following the launch, the first 12 hours of flight were taken up by on-orbit checkout (OOCO), during which the payload bay doors were opened, the SRTM system was activated and checked, and the orbiter was maneuvered to the mapping attitude. Mapping continued for 149 orbits (222.4 hours). Data were acquired at the rate of 180 megabits per second (Mbps) (C radar) and at 90 Mbps (X radar). Selected snapshots of data necessary for near-real-time performance assessment were down linked via the shuttle Ku band and NASA’s tracking and data relay system (TDRS) link to JPL in Pasadena and to the Payload Operations Control Center (POCC) in Houston.
dataset: A total of 765 data takes were executed. Of these, 399 were C radar only, 1 was X radar only, and 365 were simultaneous C and X radar. The volume of data produced by SRTM, 12.3 Tb (8.6 Tb by C radar, 3.7 Tb by X radar), compares to the capacity of the Library of Congress.

Verification.Question: Is the spatial resolution of the processed digital elevation model data, after projection conversion, 90 meters?

Disjunctive.Question: Which data collection method is more effective for producing a digital elevation model: synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry or optical stereo mapping systems?
In the context of the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission, is the C radar or X radar more suitable for achieving higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR)?
For a comprehensive digital elevation model covering 80% of Earth’s land surface, should the focus be on global coverage consistency or resolution and accuracy?

Concept Completion.Question: What is the primary data source for creating digital elevation models of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Where are the challenges most evident in conventional topographic mapping technologies?
Who are the key contributors to the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission?
Concept Completion.Answer: NASA, National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency, German Space Agency, Italian Space Agency

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to generate digital elevation models in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method is the use of the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) data, which involved synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry to acquire high-resolution digital elevation models.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in creating consistent digital elevation models on a global scale?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge is the uneven quality of conventional topographic mapping technologies, which have produced maps with varying accuracy and the difficulty in achieving consistent global coverage due to factors like cloud cover and low contrast areas.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset generated using radar technology that covers a significant portion of Earth's land surface?
Example.Answer: An example is the dataset acquired by the SRTM, which aimed to cover land between 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, encompassing approximately 80% of Earth's land surface, using both C and X radar to produce a total of 12.3 Tb of data.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific characteristics of the digital elevation model produced by the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission?
Feature Specification.Answer: high-resolution coverage, synthetic aperture radar interferometry, covers land between 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, captures approximately 80% of the Earth's land surface, spatial resolution of 90 meters, consistent scale and resolution

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges associated with conventional topographic mapping technologies highlighted in the context?
Feature Specification.Answer: uneven quality, uneven global coverage, difficult and expensive to create consistently scaled and resolved global map set, poor control, matching difficulties in low contrast areas, persistent cloud cover

Feature Specification.Question: What are the properties and data processing techniques used to generate the slope map of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: 90 meters spatial resolution, mosaicking, interpolation for Nodata values, Albers equal-area conic projection, slope aspects calculation, digital slope distribution, degree information

Quantification.Question: How many orbits were utilized during the data collection process for acquiring a digital elevation model?
How much data in terabytes was produced by the radar systems during the mission?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'interferometric SAR (InSAR)' in data collection methods?
Definition.Answer: Interferometric SAR (InSAR) is a data collection method that uses phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio (typically 0.0002) to measure topography. This method was instrumental in the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission for creating a global digital elevation model.

Definition.Question: How is 'spatial resolution' defined in the context of digital elevation models?
Definition.Answer: In the context of digital elevation models, 'spatial resolution' refers to the level of detail present in the data, with the metadata indicating a spatial resolution of 90m. This means that each data point in the digital elevation model represents a ground area of 90 meters by 90 meters.

Comparison.Question: How does the accuracy of digital elevation models created using Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM) data compare to those generated by conventional topographic mapping technologies?
Comparison.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality, with some maps showing astounding accuracy and others being far less adequate. The SRTM project, however, aimed to create a more consistent and high-resolution digital elevation model of the Earth's surface, leveraging synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry to efficiently and affordably achieve this goal.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data acquisition rates and capacities between the C radar and X radar systems used in the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission?
Comparison.Answer: During the SRTM, data were acquired at the rate of 180 megabits per second (Mbps) for C radar and 90 Mbps for X radar. The total volume of data produced was 12.3 terabytes, with 8.6 terabytes by C radar and 3.7 terabytes by X radar.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the spatial resolution of the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission data differ from the spatial resolution achieved through conventional mapping means, and what impact does this have on the quality of topographic maps produced?
Comparison.Answer: The spatial resolution achieved by SRTM data, after processing, was 90 meters, which is consistent and high-resolution compared to the uneven quality of maps produced by conventional topographic mapping technologies. This high spatial resolution contributes to the production of more accurate and reliable digital elevation models.

Interpretation.Question: How does the use of synthetic aperture radar interferometry in data collection influence the resolution and accuracy of digital elevation models?
Interpretation.Answer: Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, leverages phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio to measure topography, allowing for the efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model with consistent scale and resolution.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise from conventional topographic mapping technologies when aiming to produce a digital elevation model with global coverage?
Interpretation.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality, making it exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution. Challenges include poor control and matching difficulties in optical stereo mapping systems, especially in regions with low contrast and persistent cloud cover.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could data acquisition techniques used in radar missions be optimized to ensure consistent data quality for automated digital elevation model production?
Interpretation.Answer: To achieve consistent data quality suitable for automated production, it is essential to remove variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and accurately measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects during data acquisition.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the variability and decorrelation in pass-to-pass observations during data acquisition for digital elevation models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The key to successful acquisition of a dataset suitable for automated production is to remove the variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and to measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects accurately at all times during data acquisition.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to produce a global digital elevation model with consistent scale and resolution using conventional topographic mapping technologies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality: some with astounding accuracy, some far less adequate. Furthermore, the global coverage has been uneven, making it exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the difficulty in achieving high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in radar mapping systems, and how does this affect data quality?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The X band radar had a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) than the C band system. The variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations can affect the data quality, and accurate measurement of the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects is crucial during data acquisition.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry techniques on the quality and consistency of digital elevation models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The emergence of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry allowed for the efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model with consistent scale and resolution, overcoming the challenges of uneven quality in conventional topographic mapping technologies.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of multiple radar systems, such as C band and X band, impact the data quality and resolution in elevation mapping?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The inclusion of both C band and X band radars allowed for better quality data, as the X band radar had a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) than the C band system, contributing to better data quality and resolution.

Causal Consequence.Question: What results from the integration of mosaic processing and interpolation techniques in handling Nodata values in elevation datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The integration of mosaic processing and interpolation techniques allows for the filling in of Nodata values, thereby completing the dataset and enabling further processing such as projection conversions and boundary cutting to refine the digital elevation models.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary goal of using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry in the creation of digital elevation models for large geographical areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary goal is to efficiently and affordably create a global digital elevation model by measuring topography through phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images, providing consistent scale and resolution.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to achieve contiguous mapping coverage in the acquisition of digital elevation models for regions like the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Contiguous mapping coverage is crucial to meet the mission objectives of acquiring a comprehensive digital elevation model of all land between 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, which covers about 80% of Earth’s land surface, ensuring uniformity and completeness in topographic data collection.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in utilizing interferometric SAR (InSAR) to create a digital elevation model for a geographically extensive area like the Tibetan Plateau?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involve using phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio to measure topography. The data acquisition includes removing variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and accurately measuring the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is the data preprocessing handled to ensure consistency and quality in elevation data obtained from radar mapping missions before generating a slope map?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Data preprocessing includes merging individual data frames, using interpolation to fill Nodata values, conducting projection transformation to an Albers equal-area conic projection, and cutting the digital elevation model (DEM) using a regional boundary before utilizing spatial analysis tools to calculate slope direction and generate a slope map.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are commonly faced during the data collection process of global digital elevation models, and how can they be addressed to achieve consistent scale and resolution?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges include uneven quality of conventional topographic maps, difficulties with optical stereo mapping systems in areas of low contrast and cloud cover, and the high cost of producing a consistent global map set. These challenges can be addressed by using synthetic aperture radar interferometry techniques, which allow for efficient and affordable creation of global digital elevation models.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enabled the generation of consistent digital elevation models using radar data in geosciences?
Enablement.Answer: The advancement of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry in the 1990s enabled the efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model by using phase-difference measurements from two radar images to measure topography.

Enablement.Question: How do operational strategies during radar data collection ensure the production of high-quality digital elevation models?
Enablement.Answer: Operational strategies such as removing variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations, and accurately measuring the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects, were key to acquiring a dataset suitable for automated production of digital elevation models.

Enablement.Question: What challenges have historically hindered the production of global digital elevation models, and how have recent methodologies addressed these challenges?
Enablement.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies faced issues of uneven map quality, global coverage, and difficulties in areas with low contrast or persistent cloud cover. Recent methodologies using interferometric SAR have addressed these challenges by enabling the efficient creation of global digital elevation models with consistent scale and resolution.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to achieve consistent global map sets or digital elevation models using conventional topographic mapping technologies?
Expectation.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality: some with astounding accuracy, some far less adequate. Furthermore, the global coverage has been uneven. It has proven exceedingly difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution by conventional means.

Expectation.Question: What expectations might researchers have when using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry for digital elevation model creation?
Expectation.Answer: The emergence of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry in the 1990s placed the possibility of efficiently and affordably creating a global digital elevation model within the grasp of spacefaring nations. Interferometric SAR, or InSAR, makes use of phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio to measure topography.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be discrepancies in the quality of data collected by different radar systems during a mission?
Expectation.Answer: The SRTM mission included both C radar and X radar systems. The X radar was included as an experimental demonstration and had a slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) than the C band system. The key to successful acquisition of a dataset suitable for automated production is to remove the variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations and to measure the interferometer baseline and other systematic effects accurately at all times during data acquisition.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential limitations of using data from multiple radar systems, and how might these affect the overall quality of a digital elevation model?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multiple radar systems, such as C and X bands, presents the challenge of ensuring consistent data quality and coverage. The variability and decorrelation due to pass-to-pass observations need to be carefully managed, and systematic effects must be accurately measured to maintain the integrity of the digital elevation model.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways do the methods used in data acquisition impact the reliability and processing of datasets in digital elevation modeling?
Judgmental.Answer: The methods used in data acquisition, such as those employed by SRTM, involve precise operations like on-orbit checkout and continuous data acquisition over multiple orbits. These methods are crucial for minimizing errors and ensuring the reliability of the datasets, as they allow for the real-time assessment and correction of data quality issues during the mission.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the challenges of conventional topographic mapping technologies impact the quality and consistency of digital elevation models.
Assertion.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality, with some having astounding accuracy and others being far less adequate. Additionally, global coverage by these methods has been uneven, making it difficult and expensive to produce a global map set or digital elevation model of consistent scale and resolution.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how the data collection method used in SAR interferometry enables the creation of a global digital elevation model.
Assertion.Answer: SAR interferometry, or InSAR, makes use of phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio (typically 0.0002) to measure topography. This method allows for the efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the operational objectives and how they influence the data collection strategy for digital elevation models.
Assertion.Answer: The operational objective was to acquire a digital elevation model of all land between about 60° north latitude and 56° south latitude, covering about 80% of Earth’s land surface. The strategy involved generating contiguous mapping coverage with the C radar, while the X radar was included as an experimental demonstration with slightly higher resolution and better signal-to-noise ratio.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges of conventional topographic mapping technologies and how they compare to synthetic aperture radar interferometry in producing digital elevation models.
Request/Directive.Answer: Conventional topographic mapping technologies have produced maps of uneven quality, with some having astounding accuracy and others being far less adequate. Furthermore, the global coverage from these conventional methods has been uneven and difficult to achieve. Optical stereo mapping systems face challenges such as poor control and matching difficulties in areas of low contrast and persistent cloud cover in many important areas of the world. In contrast, synthetic aperture radar (SAR) interferometry, particularly InSAR, makes use of phase-difference measurements derived from two radar images acquired with a very small base to height ratio (typically 0.0002) to measure topography. This method allows for efficient and affordable creation of a global digital elevation model, addressing the challenges faced by conventional methods.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used during the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission to acquire digital elevation models.
Request/Directive.Answer: Following the launch of the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission, the first 12 hours of flight were dedicated to on-orbit checkout (OOCO), during which the payload bay doors were opened, the SRTM system was activated and checked, and the orbiter was maneuvered to the mapping attitude. Mapping continued for 149 orbits, spanning 222.4 hours. Data were acquired at rates of 180 megabits per second (Mbps) for C radar and 90 Mbps for X radar. Selected snapshots of data required for near-real-time performance assessment were downlinked via the shuttle Ku band and NASA’s tracking and data relay system (TDRS) link to JPL in Pasadena and to the Payload Operations Control Center (POCC) in Houston.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets generated from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission and their significance for geospatial research.
Request/Directive.Answer: The Shuttle Radar Topography Mission produced a total of 765 data takes, of which 399 were C radar only, 1 was X radar only, and 365 were simultaneous C and X radar. The volume of data produced by the mission was 12.3 Tb, with 8.6 Tb by C radar and 3.7 Tb by X radar. This dataset is highly significant for geospatial research as it represents one of the most complete, highest-resolution digital elevation models of the Earth's surface, providing foundational knowledge for modern geosciences and facilitating consistent scale and resolution mapping over about 80% of the Earth's land surface.
